section.title: about buses
section.para: Hardware components communicate with the Central Processing Unitcpu or cpu over a busbus. The most common buses today are usbusb, pcipci, agpagp, pci-expresspci-express and pcmciapcmcia aka pc-cardpc-card. These are all Plag and Play buses.
Older x86 computers often had isaisa buses, which can be confugred using jumpers or dip switches.

section.title: /proc/bus
section.para: To list the buses recognized by the Linux kernel on your computer, look at the contents of the /proc/bus//proc/bus directory (screenshot from Ubuntu 7.04 and RHEL4u4 below).
section.screen: root@laika:~# ls /proc/bus/ input pccard pci usb
section.para: Can you guess which of these two screenshots was taken on a laptop ?

section.title: /usr/sbin/lsusb
section.para: To list all the usb devices connected to your system, you could read the contents of /proc/bus/usb/devices/proc/bus/usb/devices (if it exists) or you could use the more readable output of lsusblsusb, which is executed here on a SPARC system with Ubuntu.

section.title: about interrupts
section.para: An interrupt requestinterrupt or IRQIRQ is a request from a device to the CPU. A device raises an interrupt when it requires the attention of the CPU (could be because the device has data ready to be read by the CPU).
Since the introduction of pci, irq's can be shared among devices.
Interrupt 0 is always reserved for the timer, interrupt 1 for the keyboard. IRQ 2 is used as a channel for IRQ's 8 to 15, and thus is the same as IRQ 9.

section.para: You can see a listing of interrupts on your system in /proc/interrupts/proc/interrupts.

section.title: about io ports
section.para: Communication in the other direction, from CPU to device, happens through IO portsIO Ports. The CPU writes data or control codes to the IO port of the device. But this is not only a one way communication, the CPU can also use a device's IO port to read status information about the device. Unlike interrupts, ports cannot be shared!

section.title: /proc/ioports
section.para: You can see a listing of your system's IO ports via /proc/ioports/proc/ioports.

section.title: about dma
section.para: A device that needs a lot of data, interrupts and ports can pose a heavy load on the cpu. With dmadma or Direct Memory Access a device can gain (temporary) access to a specific range of the ram memory.

section.title: /proc/dma
section.para: Looking at /proc/dma/proc/dma might not give you the information that you want, since it only contains currently assigned dma channels for isa devices.

pci devices that are using dma are not listed in /proc/dma, in this case dmesgdmesg(1) can be useful. The screenshot below shows that during boot the parallel port received dma channel 1, and the Infrared port received dma channel 3.
